title: Natural Disasters Survival Guide - Concise Edition
content: Concise survival protocols for earthquakes, hurricanes, floods, tornadoes, and other disasters

chunks.content:
üåç **EARTHQUAKES**

Earthquakes strike without warning when tectonic plates shift along fault lines. They last seconds to minutes and cause ground shaking, building collapse, and aftershocks that can continue for months.

**What To Do:**
‚Ä¢ **DROP** to hands and knees immediately
‚Ä¢ **COVER** head and neck under sturdy furniture
‚Ä¢ **HOLD ON** and stay put until shaking stops
‚Ä¢ If in bed, stay there and cover head with pillow
‚Ä¢ If outdoors, move away from buildings to open area
‚Ä¢ If driving, pull over away from structures and stay inside
‚Ä¢ DON'T run outside - falling debris is deadly
‚Ä¢ DON'T use elevators
‚Ä¢ DON'T stand in doorways - not safer than other spots

**After It Stops:**
‚Ä¢ Wait 60 seconds before moving - let your brain reorient
‚Ä¢ Check for injuries and treat bleeding first
‚Ä¢ Expect aftershocks - get back to safety if shaking resumes
‚Ä¢ Check for gas leaks (smell/hissing), electrical damage (sparks), structural damage (cracks)
‚Ä¢ Turn off gas and electricity if damaged
‚Ä¢ Use stairs only, never elevators
‚Ä¢ Listen to battery radio for updates

üåä **FLOODS**

Floods are the most common natural disaster. Flash floods can occur within minutes with walls of water 10+ feet high. Just 6 inches of moving water knocks you down. 12 inches floats most cars. 2 feet sweeps away vehicles.

**What To Do:**
‚Ä¢ **Evacuate immediately** if ordered - don't wait
‚Ä¢ Move to highest ground available
‚Ä¢ NEVER walk, swim, or drive through flood water
‚Ä¢ If trapped in building, go to highest floor (NOT attic unless you have axe to cut through roof)
‚Ä¢ Call 911 and give your exact location
‚Ä¢ Wave bright cloth from window, flash lights at night

**If Vehicle Stalls in Water:**
‚Ä¢ Abandon it immediately - water rises fast
‚Ä¢ Move to high ground right away
‚Ä¢ Don't go back for belongings

**Why Flood Water Is Deadly:**
‚Ä¢ Hides downed power lines (entire area electrified)
‚Ä¢ Contains sewage, chemicals, sharp debris
‚Ä¢ Conceals deep holes and collapsed roads
‚Ä¢ Harbors snakes, alligators, fire ants
‚Ä¢ Currents much stronger than they appear

**Remember:** Turn Around Don't Drown - no destination is worth your life

üåÄ **HURRICANES**

Hurricanes are massive rotating storms with winds 74+ mph. Storm surge (ocean pushed ashore) causes 90% of deaths, not wind. Categories 3-5 are major hurricanes with catastrophic damage.

**What To Do:**
‚Ä¢ **Evacuate if ordered** - storm surge is unsurvivable
‚Ä¢ If in evacuation zone A, B, or C - you must leave
‚Ä¢ DON'T stay for Category 3+ hurricanes
‚Ä¢ Board windows and bring in all outdoor items
‚Ä¢ Fill vehicles with gas NOW - stations lose power
‚Ä¢ Withdraw cash - ATMs will fail
‚Ä¢ Fill bathtubs and containers with water

**If Staying (ONLY Cat 1-2, NOT in surge zone):**
‚Ä¢ Go to interior first-floor room away from windows
‚Ä¢ Stay there during entire storm
‚Ä¢ Keep radio on for updates

**During The Eye:**
‚Ä¢ DON'T go outside when winds stop
‚Ä¢ Eye is temporary calm - winds return from opposite direction within 30 minutes
‚Ä¢ Most injuries happen during eye

**After Storm:**
‚Ä¢ Wait for official all-clear
‚Ä¢ Avoid ALL standing water - electrified from downed lines
‚Ä¢ Never touch downed power lines
‚Ä¢ Don't drive through water - 6 inches sweeps vehicles away
‚Ä¢ Use generator OUTSIDE only - carbon monoxide kills indoors

üå™Ô∏è **TORNADOES**

Tornadoes are violently rotating columns of air with winds up to 300 mph. They sound like freight trains and form quickly from thunderstorms. EF5 tornadoes cause total destruction.

**What To Do:**
‚Ä¢ **Take shelter immediately** when warning issued
‚Ä¢ Go to basement southwest corner if you have one
‚Ä¢ No basement? Interior room on lowest floor (bathroom, closet, hallway)
‚Ä¢ Get in bathtub if it's sturdy, cover with mattress
‚Ä¢ Stay away from windows and exterior walls
‚Ä¢ Get low, cover head and neck with arms

**If In Mobile Home:**
‚Ä¢ LEAVE immediately to permanent shelter
‚Ä¢ Mobile homes are death traps - they disintegrate in strong tornadoes
‚Ä¢ Find substantial building or designated shelter

**If Caught Outside:**
‚Ä¢ Lie flat in ditch or low area
‚Ä¢ Cover head with hands
‚Ä¢ Watch for flash flooding in low areas
‚Ä¢ DON'T hide under highway overpass - wind speeds increase, creates deadly debris tunnel

**Warning Signs:**
‚Ä¢ Dark greenish sky
‚Ä¢ Large hail
‚Ä¢ Loud roar like freight train
‚Ä¢ Rotating cloud base

**After Tornado:**
‚Ä¢ Watch for downed power lines and gas leaks
‚Ä¢ Don't use flames or electrical switches if you smell gas
‚Ä¢ Check on neighbors who may be trapped

üò∞ **PANIC & STRESS MANAGEMENT**

Your brain's stress response can save or endanger you. Panic causes tunnel vision, memory loss, and poor decisions. Staying calm is a survival skill.

**How To Stay Calm:**
‚Ä¢ **Use S.T.O.P. technique:**
  - **S**top all impulsive actions
  - **T**hink clearly about situation
  - **O**bserve surroundings and options
  - **P**roceed with best plan
‚Ä¢ Take slow, deep breaths - calms nervous system
‚Ä¢ Focus on immediate, small tasks you can control
‚Ä¢ Break large problems into tiny steps

**Physical Needs Affect Mental State:**
‚Ä¢ Stay hydrated - dehydration impairs judgment
‚Ä¢ Eat regularly - low blood sugar causes anxiety
‚Ä¢ Rest when possible - exhaustion clouds thinking
‚Ä¢ Keep moving - activity reduces stress hormones

**In A Crisis:**
‚Ä¢ Don't rush - hasty decisions are often wrong
‚Ä¢ Count to 10 before acting
‚Ä¢ Focus on what you CAN control, not what you can't
‚Ä¢ Review your options out loud
‚Ä¢ Remember: most situations have multiple solutions

**Remember:** Fear is normal and useful - it heightens awareness. Panic is fear without control. You can train yourself to stay calm.

‚ö° **POWER OUTAGES**

Power outages during disasters can last days or weeks. Loss of electricity means no lights, heat, AC, refrigeration, or way to charge devices.

**What To Do:**
‚Ä¢ Keep flashlights and battery radio accessible
‚Ä¢ Don't open refrigerator/freezer - keeps cold 4 hours (fridge) or 48 hours (full freezer)
‚Ä¢ Turn off appliances and electronics to prevent damage from power surge when electricity returns
‚Ä¢ Use generator OUTSIDE only, 20+ feet from building - carbon monoxide kills within minutes indoors
‚Ä¢ NEVER use charcoal grill, camping stove, or gas appliances indoors

**Emergency Lighting:**
‚Ä¢ Use flashlights, not candles - gas leaks cause explosions
‚Ä¢ LED flashlights last longest on batteries
‚Ä¢ Headlamps keep hands free
‚Ä¢ Don't waste phone battery on flashlight - save for emergency calls

**Food Safety:**
‚Ä¢ Refrigerator safe 4 hours without power
‚Ä¢ Full freezer safe 48 hours, half-full 24 hours
‚Ä¢ Keep doors closed to maintain temperature
‚Ä¢ Throw away perishables after these times
‚Ä¢ When in doubt, throw it out

**Stay Warm/Cool:**
‚Ä¢ Close off unused rooms
‚Ä¢ Wear layers indoors
‚Ä¢ Use blankets to stay warm
‚Ä¢ Drink plenty of water in heat

üè† **SHELTER (Wilderness)**

Exposure to cold, wind, and wet conditions kills faster than hunger or thirst. Shelter is your #1 priority in survival situations.

**What To Do:**
‚Ä¢ Choose high, dry ground away from flood zones
‚Ä¢ Find natural windbreaks (dense trees, rock outcrops, hillsides)
‚Ä¢ Avoid animal trails and insect nests
‚Ä¢ Build lean-to with ridgepole between two trees
‚Ä¢ Layer branches at 45-degree angle against ridgepole
‚Ä¢ Cover with leaves, pine needles, bark for insulation
‚Ä¢ Make bed 12+ inches thick with dry material - ground steals body heat

**In Snow:**
‚Ä¢ Dig snow cave or quinzhee
‚Ä¢ Smooth interior walls to prevent dripping
‚Ä¢ Make small entrance below sleeping platform
‚Ä¢ Poke ventilation hole in roof - carbon dioxide sinks

**Key Rules:**
‚Ä¢ Insulate from ground - it's the biggest heat thief
‚Ä¢ Stay dry - wet clothes lose 90% of insulation
‚Ä¢ Make shelter small - easier to heat with body warmth
‚Ä¢ Build fire pit 10+ feet downwind from shelter

üíß **WATER (Wilderness)**

You can survive 3 weeks without food but only 3 days without water. Finding and purifying water is critical.

**How To Find Water:**
‚Ä¢ Follow animal tracks - usually lead to water
‚Ä¢ Look for green vegetation in valleys
‚Ä¢ Listen for running water
‚Ä¢ Collect morning dew with cloth, wring into container
‚Ä¢ Dig in dry stream beds - water often flows underground
‚Ä¢ Collect rainwater in clean containers

**How To Purify:**
‚Ä¢ **Boil for 1 minute** (most reliable method)
‚Ä¢ Wait for water to cool before drinking
‚Ä¢ At high altitude (6,500+ feet), boil 3 minutes

**What NOT To Drink:**
‚Ä¢ DON'T drink urine - concentrates toxins and salt
‚Ä¢ DON'T drink seawater - causes fatal dehydration
‚Ä¢ DON'T drink blood - requires water to digest
‚Ä¢ Avoid stagnant water if possible

**Signs of Dehydration:**
‚Ä¢ Dark yellow urine
‚Ä¢ Headache and dizziness
‚Ä¢ Dry mouth
‚Ä¢ Fatigue
‚Ä¢ Confusion (severe)

**Remember:** Always purify water, even if it looks clean. Giardia and other parasites cause severe illness.

üî• **FIRE (Wilderness)**

Fire provides warmth, purifies water, signals rescuers, and boosts morale. Building fire is a core survival skill.

**What You Need:**
‚Ä¢ **Tinder** (catches spark): dry grass, bark shavings, cotton, dryer lint
‚Ä¢ **Kindling** (small fuel): twigs, small dry sticks (pencil-thick)
‚Ä¢ **Fuel** (sustains fire): larger branches and logs

**How To Build:**
‚Ä¢ Clear area down to bare soil in 10-foot circle
‚Ä¢ Make tinder bundle size of fist
‚Ä¢ Arrange kindling in teepee or log cabin shape over tinder
‚Ä¢ Light tinder from multiple sides
‚Ä¢ Add kindling gradually as fire grows
‚Ä¢ Add larger fuel once kindling catches
‚Ä¢ Keep fuel dry and staged nearby

**Fire Safety:**
‚Ä¢ Build 10+ feet from shelter and trees
‚Ä¢ Never leave fire unattended
‚Ä¢ Keep water nearby to extinguish
‚Ä¢ Fully extinguish before leaving - drown, stir, drown again
‚Ä¢ Check that ashes are cold to touch

**Alternative Fire Starters:**
‚Ä¢ Flint and steel
‚Ä¢ Fire piston
‚Ä¢ Magnifying glass (sunny day)
‚Ä¢ Friction methods (bow drill, hand drill) - difficult, last resort
